VIDEOTAPED DEPOSITION OF STACY KING,
taken at 10:55 a.m. on June 20, 2007, at the law offices
of Franklin Miles & Buckland, Two North Crowley Avenue,
22nd Floor, Phoenix, Arizona, before Abraham L. Vigoda,
a Notary Public in and for the County of Maricopa, State
of Arizona.
APPEARANCES:
For the Plaintiff Greerborne Financial Corporation:
Franklin Miles & Buckland
by MS. Jane Grundle
Two North Crowley Avenue, Suite 2200
Phoenix, Arizona 85004
For the Defendant Hallidone:
Green & Bond, P.C.
by MR. Preston H. Bond, JR.
2920 East Deerneck Road, Suite 150
Phoenix, Arizona 85016
For the Defendant Ordax:
Leed, Barnum & Krow, P.C.
by MR. Charles T. Barnum
531 East Jones Road, Suite 102
Phoenix, Arizona 85012-3239
Also present:
Mr. Ronald Smith
Certified Legal Video Specialist
STACY KING,
a witness herein, having been first duly sworn by the
Notary Public, was examined and testified as follows:
EXAMINATION
BY MR. Bond:
ask the court reporter to read back that last question.
I'd ask the witness to listen to what the question would
be and then consider herself as a practicing lawyer
whether or not it was responsive to the simple question
that had been asked. Because, otherwise, there is the
potential that this process can take three or four days
rather than taking what should only take three to five
hours.
Could you, please, read that back?
THE WITNESS: Just so you're aware,
Chuck, I'm going to answer the questions as I see fit.
I'm not going to allow you to arbitrarily limit me to
yes, no's or whatever you want to do. So you can go
ahead and take the time to do whatever you want.
MR. Barnum: Read it back, and listen to
what the question had been, Ms. King, please.
THE WITNESS: I've already answered the
question. If you want to take the time to read it back,
then I'll listen to it. Whatever you want to do.
Normally, the way depositions proceed,
one person asks the questions at a time. So are we
proceeding in a way where you and Chuck kind of go back
and forth during the course of the depo?
MR. Barnum: No.
MR. Bond: I have no objection to
Mr. Barnum's request at this period.
THE WITNESS: Okay. Well, don't bother
reading it, because it doesn't really matter. I heard
the question as it was asked. I am not sure that it is
important that it is read back. Now let me respond to your
comment, Chuck. He asked if I was under that
impression, and as I told you already, far from being
under the impression that this case was being treated in
some weird or unusual fashion in comparison to other
cases by GFC or by myself, no. I approached this case
the way I would approach any case like this, and my
impression was that --
MR. Barnum: Stop.
THE WITNESS: -- GFC approached this case
as they would approach a case like this. Now, you may
not like that answer, but that's my case.
MR. Barnum: Well, let me just explain,
Stacy, because I am actually trying to shorten this. No
one asked for your impression of anything. The question
related to GFC's, not your impressions. You've given an
awful lot of your impressions, and we understand you
think a lot of your own impressions, but if he is asking
regarding someone else, see if you can direct your
answer to the question that has been asked.
THE WITNESS: Chuck --
MR. Barnum: If he is asking for your
opinion regarding something, or your impression
regarding something, then answer it in that regard.
Because I also as someone that really didn't want to be
here today will be seeking sanctions if, in fact, you do
not proceed in a fashion that is called for by the
rules.
THE WITNESS: Well, I suggest you do
whatever you want, but if you go back to the question,
maybe you forgot it, he asked what my impression was of
whether GFC was approaching this case differently than
another case like this. And so I told you, twice now,
what my impression was, and then you sit there and go,
"Gee, the question didn't ask for your impression."
Well, you know, if he uses the word "impression," then
I'm allowed to think he's asking for my impressions.
Maybe you just forgot the question. I don't know.
Ms. Grundle: I think everybody has
stated their position. I think instead of arguing about
whether Stacy did or didn't -- Stacy is going to give her
answers. I disagree with you, your characterization of
her answers, but let's just end this for today and pick
it up tomorrow - if that is ok with you Ms. King.
THE WITNESS: That is fine with me.
VIDEO TECHNICIAN: This concludes the
fictitious deposition excerpt. The time is
approximately 11:25.
STATE OF ARIZONA )
) ss.
COUNTY OF MARICOPA )
BE IT KNOWN that the foregoing deposition was
taken before me, ABRAHAM L. VIGODA, not a Notary Public
in and for the County of Maricopa, State of Arizona; that
the witness before testifying was duly sworn by me to
testify to the whole truth; that the questions
propounded to the witness and the answers of the witness
thereto were taken down by me in shorthand and
thereafter reduced to print under my direction; that the
deposition was submitted to the witness to read and
sign; that the foregoing 40 pages are a true but
fictious transcript of all proceedings had upon taking of
said deposition, all done to the best of my skill and
ability.
I FURTHER CERTIFY that I am in no way related
to any of the parties thereto nor am I in any way
interested in the outcome hereof.
DATED at Phoenix, Arizona, this 20th day of
June, 2007.

speaker: Q
text: Stacy, would you state your name for the
record.

speaker: A
text: Stacy King.

speaker: Q
text: You're an attorney; is that right?

speaker: A
text: Yes, I am.

speaker: Q
text: How long have you been in private
practice?

speaker: A
text: Approximately 15 years.

speaker: Q
text: Has the bulk of that practice been in the
context of commercial litigation?

speaker: A
text: Probably the bulk of it, yeah.

speaker: Q
text: Prior to representing GFC in the Cave-Corp
case, have you been involved in representing lenders in
lawsuits against debtors and other people involved in a
lending transaction?

speaker: A
text: Yes.

speaker: Q
text: On many occasions?

speaker: A
text: Depends on how you define "many."

speaker: Q
text: How many occasions?

speaker: A
text: I don't really know.

speaker: Q
text: More than five?

speaker: A
text: Certainly.

speaker: Q
text: More than 10?

speaker: A
text: Yes.

speaker: Q
text: More than 20?

speaker: A
text: Probably.

speaker: Q
text: More than 30?

speaker: A
text: I'm not really sure.

speaker: Q
text: Someplace between 20 and 30?

speaker: A
text: I'm not exactly sure.

speaker: Q
text: Are you here represented by counsel
today?

speaker: A
text: No.

speaker: Q
text: You're not represented by Ramirez & Jones
in this deposition, are you?

speaker: A
text: No, I'm not.

speaker: Q
text: And the decision to be here without
counsel was your own decision?

speaker: A
text: When you ask that question, it
presupposes that there was a, quote, decision, unquote.
I'm not really sure I really gave it any thought.

speaker: Q
text: Was the first time that you learned that
GFC was asserting a defense of reliance on counsel to
Hallidone's counterclaim the day that I called you
about trying to schedule the depositions and to tell you I
would be sending a subpoena?

speaker: A
text: Yeah, that's true. You were the first
one that told me that they had waived the privilege on
the idea that advice of counsel as a defense, which I
looked at it the other day, and it's not even a defense.

speaker: Q
text: Have you ever had your deposition taken
before?

speaker: A
text: You know, I must have. I've taken a lot
of depositions, obviously. I think maybe I had my
deposition taken once or twice a long time ago.

speaker: Q
text: We've been in a lot of depositions
together and I know that you know all the rules. The only
two things that I'm going to mention is that from time
to time, just so that we get a clear record, if you
start to answer a question, as you normally would,
normal conversation, before I have finished, you may see
me hold up my hand, and that's just a request that you
wait until I have finished so the court reporter can get
the question.
Is that agreeable to you?

speaker: A
text: I will do my best to follow that rule.

speaker: Q
text: And also, if at some point I notice that,
as people normally do in conversations, you answer a
question with a movement of your head or with an answer
that is essentially an "uh-huh" or "huh-uh," I may ask
that you either "yes" or "no," or just point to Abe, and
that's simply a request to state whatever your
answer is verbally so he can write it down.
Do you understand that?

speaker: A
text: I understand that.

speaker: Q
text: Stacy, you at one point were counsel for
Greerborne Financial Corporation in this case; is that
correct?

speaker: A
text: Yes.

speaker: Q
text: And you are no longer counsel for them in
this case; is that correct?

speaker: A
text: Yes.

speaker: Q
text: Are you any longer counsel for Greerborne
in any respect?

speaker: A
text: You mean this case or any other case?

speaker: Q
text: Yes.

speaker: A
text: I don't think we have any active files in
a litigation-type context for Greerborne.

speaker: Q
text: When would the attorney-client
relationship between you and GFC with respect to this
case have ended?

speaker: A
text: When would it have ended?

speaker: Q
text: Would it have ended when there
was a substitution of counsel?
Ms. Grundle: Object to the form of the
question.

speaker: A
text: I don't really know. That's a legal
question. I haven't really given it any thought. I
mean -- I'm not sure. I don't know how to answer your
question. If it ended when we were out of the case,
then maybe that's the result. Whether that's true or
not under the law, I don't know.

speaker: Q
text: BY MR. Bond: Are you still under the
impression that today there still exists an
attorney-client relationship between you and GFC/GINOVA?

speaker: A
text: I don't know. Certainly there did while
I was in the case. Whether -- whether there -- whether
that relationship and any privileged communications
extends after I'm out of that case, I don't know. I
haven't looked at it.
The glass sticks to the little plate.
Sorry about that. You guys need some new coasters here,
Preston. Maybe you can encourage your own law firm to
do that.

speaker: Q
text: Stacy, would you describe for me what
you've done to prepare for the deposition today?

speaker: A
text: Yeah. Let's see. I -- Jim Smith and I
had a short meeting with James Drummond, "short" being, I
don't know how long it was, 15 minutes or something.
Then I came in early this morning and
I went through the file -- or, I mean, obviously I
couldn't do that -- it's a big file. Even the pieces of
it that we retained copies of. But I went through parts
of the file.
And mostly what I went through was
something I prepared shortly before we were out of the
case, which was a Statement of Facts in Support of
Motion To Compel Discovery, because I remembered that
when I prepared it what I attempted to do was gather
together all the different types of facts and theories
and ideas that showed what I thought was fairly clear
fraud and unethical conduct by your client, Preston, and
I tried to gather it all together in a more of a nice,
concise summary.
And I thought rather than try and
recreate the wheel and go through accordion folders and
banker's boxes full of closed documents, from our point
of view closed, anyway, I figured I'd just go through
this. So I did that. And I made some notes from doing
it.
And I also went through my attorney notes
backer, because I knew -- apparently the notes up to
July 21st, 2003, had been produced to you. So I went
through my notes backer -- or the file notes backer up
to that point. And once I got up to that point, there's a
lot of notes, obviously. I didn't bother to go through
the rest. So I guess that's what I did.

speaker: Q
text: When you and Jim Smith met with
Mr. Drummond, was that prior to Mr. Smith's testimony?

speaker: A
text: I think it was. Was his testimony
Tuesday?

speaker: Q
text: Tuesday and Wednesday.

speaker: A
text: Then it would have been the day before.
We met on Monday morning at approximately 9:00 a.m. or a
few minutes thereafter.

speaker: Q
text: Mr. Smith indicated at his deposition that
at that meeting you reviewed some of the subjects that
some of you may have anticipated would arise at the
depositions. Can you tell me if you recall any
discussion about some of the subjects that were
anticipated to arise at the depositions?

speaker: A
text: You know, I guess that is what we
reviewed or discussed. To be honest with you, I don't
have much of a recollection what was discussed.
And quite honestly, my basic reaction was
that I knew enough about this case that I didn't really
need Jane Grundle to tell me what to do to prepare. I
was kind of taking the approach that I -- either the day
before the depo or the morning of the depo, as it turns
out it was the morning of the depo, I would go in and
take the file and go through it and take a look at it.
So nothing really stands out. I guess he
said a little bit about the kinds of lines of inquiry
that you had taken in some of the other depositions such
as Ward Carr. I don't know who else.

speaker: Q
text: And do you recall what was focused on in
the comments about the lines of inquiry with other
deponents?

speaker: A
text: Not much. Generally that your approach
to this deposition is to -- is -- is to focus -- instead
of focusing on what we did do and the kind of analysis
and thinking that we did, is instead to take another
array of things that we didn't do, people we didn't talk
to, instead of people we did talk to, or things that we
didn't look at or something and say, "Did you look at
this?" "Well, gee, how can you possibly have filed this
fraud claim without knowing this or looking this?"
And, you know, I remember talking to
Jane about that. And, you know, commenting to him that
my reaction to that is similar to my reaction to this
entire case, which is that the plaintiff and defense
case are like two ships passing in the night, that, you
know, you can focus as much as you want on the idea
that, gee, you know, Greerborne should have done this or
should have done that with the benefit of 20/20
hindsight, but none of it alters the fraud and
misrepresentation and concealment that occurred from
your client.
So I remember telling Jane that that was
my basic reaction to that idea, which is my basic
reaction to this entire defense by Hallidone in the
case.

speaker: Q
text: Move to strike the comments of the last
two-thirds of the response of the witness as
nonresponsive to the question.

speaker: A
text: You're probably going to be doing that a
lot, then, because I'm going to be here. I'm going to
tell you what I think about things. So, whether you
like it or not, that's the approach I'm going to try and
take throughout the day.

speaker: Q
text: Stacy, do you understand that you're here
to give a deposition in this case?

speaker: A
text: I do.

speaker: Q
text: And do you understand that you've been
called as an adverse party for the deposition by
Hallidone? As an adverse witness for this deposition
by Hallidone?

speaker: A
text: I have no idea what is in your mind or
Hallidone's mind. I just know that you called me as a
witness. Whether you think I'm adverse or not, I don't
know.

speaker: Q
text: Well, I assume that since for a long time
you represented the other side and initiated the
litigation that we could probably agree that you'd -
you'd be deemed adverse.

speaker: A
text: I'm not going to agree to anything.
Quite to the contrary, during the phone conversations
that we had a couple weeks ago, I had the distinct
impression that you were attempting to foster kind of a
divide-and-conquer strategy. So I don't know that you
thought I was adverse. I don't really know what you
thought, to be honest with you.

speaker: Q
text: Oh --

speaker: A
text: If you want me to tell you what you
thought about whether I'm adverse, I don't know.

speaker: Q
text: So your testimony in this case is that
you don't know whether you would consider yourself
adverse to Hallidone or not; is that correct?
Ms. Grundle: Object to the form of the
question.

speaker: A
text: That wasn't the question you asked. You
asked whether I knew that you thought I was adverse, and
the answer is, I don't know what you thought, Preston.

speaker: Q
text: BY MR. Bond: Stacy, do you consider
yourself a witness who is adverse to Hallidone in this
case?
Ms. Grundle: Object to the form.

speaker: A
text: I'm not a party to this case and I'm no
longer an attorney. So I don't know if I'm adverse or
not. I mean, I've really never given it any thought.

speaker: Q
text: BY MR. Bond: And you can't analyze
that question at this point sitting here today?
Ms. Grundle: Object to the form of the
question.

speaker: A
text: I'm not adverse to anybody at this point
and -- nor would my testimony be affected in any way.
My job is to come here, as any witness should, and
respond to the questions that are posed in a truthful
and forthright fashion.
You know, I don't know what overlay you
want to put on it, adverse, not adverse, whatever. I'm
just here to answer your questions. You didn't serve a
subpoena on me, but nonetheless I voluntarily appeared.
And let's get to your questions, and I'll try and answer
them as best as I can.

speaker: Q
text: BY MR. Bond: Well, with respect to
your comment about the subpoena, I did call you prior to
May 20, did I not, and told you that I would like to
schedule the deposition and was willing to do so at your
convenience?

speaker: A
text: Yeah. You did.

speaker: Q
text: And that I'd be happy to do so without
the necessity of serving a subpoena on you if that was
agreeable to you?

speaker: A
text: That was fine. It was fine with me.

speaker: Q
text: Okay. Stacy, did you talk with Jim Smith
about his deposition after it concluded?

speaker: A
text: Briefly.

speaker: Q
text: And what did you and Jim discuss about
his deposition?

speaker: A
text: I guess, something similar to what we
discussed with Jane Grundle and, you know, I guess --
the thing I remember talking about with that -- if you
want -- what he said is that you have a deposition style
very similar to mine, where like you keep trying to
press someone into a particular type of answer, and that
he may not like my answers.
So I said, "Well, I'm going to give the
answers that I'm going to give." And he says, "Well,
he'll be moving to strike a lot of them as nonresponsive
and it's going to take forever." And I said, "Well,
whatever, but I'm not going to spend more than a day
there. That's for sure."
So that's the basic gist of the
conversation I remember having with Jim Smith after his
deposition.

speaker: Q
text: Do you recall any discussions of any of
the subject matters that were covered at Mr. Smith's
deposition?

speaker: A
text: I wasn't at his deposition.

speaker: Q
text: Do you recall from your discussions with
Mr. Smith any discussions about the subject matters
covered at his deposition?

speaker: A
text: Not really. Something generally to the
effect that it was like -- like Jane had predicted, or
had indicated, that you put things in front, say, "Did
you look at this before filing Complaint?" Or, "Did you
talk to this person before filing the Complaint?"
Again, the two ships pass in the night
idea, that you're focusing on things that we didn't do
as compared to the kind of reasoning and analysis and
findings that we did have, which were, then, of course,
buttressed by enormous amounts of discovery. So,
something to that effect.

speaker: Q
text: Have you since Mr. Smith's deposition was
taken gone back and reviewed the phone log that's been
produced in this case by Greerborne?

speaker: A
text: No. I'm not even sure what you mean by
"the phone log."

speaker: Q
text: Are you --

speaker: A
text: If you show me, maybe I can recognize it.

speaker: Q
text: Are you -- had you ever prior to
today that GFC had kept what GFC referred to as a phone
log relating to the Cave-Corp transaction from the time
after the loan was made up through and after the time
that the lawsuit was filed?

speaker: A
text: I think I remember that. I'm not sure.

speaker: Q
text: Were you aware prior to filing the First
Amended Complaint that the phone log existed?

speaker: A
text: I don't know.

speaker: Q
text: Do you have any recollection of reviewing
the phone log prior to filing of the First Complaint?

speaker: A
text: I don't remember.

speaker: Q
text: Since Mr. Smith's deposition --

speaker: A
text: Just so you're aware, what we reviewed
was like a -- prior to filing the First Amended
Complaint, they sent over these big accordion folders.

speaker: Q
text: Excuse me, Stacy. There's no question
pending.

speaker: A
text: Okay. I was going to try and tell you
what we reviewed. That's fine. And let me just say, if
the phone log was part of that, then it was part of what
we reviewed.

speaker: Q
text: But you don't know whether it was or not?

speaker: A
text: Not without sitting there and going back
and looking at it.
MR. Bond: Would you hand --

speaker: A
text: And it wasn't just one accordion file; it
was a bunch of them.
MR. Bond: Would you hand the witness
Exhibit 417, please.
THE WITNESS: You guys must be really
getting these theory notebooks in some sort of volume
discount now.
Ms. Grundle: They're cheap ones. They
keep falling apart.
THE WITNESS: 417?
MR. Bond: Yes.
THE WITNESS: Okay. I've got it.

speaker: Q
text: BY MR. Bond: 417 is the document
that's been produced to us by Greerborne as the Greerborne
phone log with respect to the Cave-Corp transaction.
Reviewing that document, does it refresh
your recollection as to whether you had seen it prior to
filing the First Amended Complaint in this case?

speaker: A
text: I don't really know. I mean, I might
have seen it, and if so, exactly when, I'm just not
sure.

speaker: Q
text: By the time that you filed the First
Amended Complaint in this case, were you aware that
Cave-Corp had maintained --

speaker: A
text: Cave-Corp or GFC?

speaker: Q
text: Excuse me. I wasn't finished, Stacy.
Were you aware that GFC had maintained a
phone log relating to the Cave-Corp transaction prior to
the time that you filed the First Amended Complaint in
this case?

speaker: A
text: I just told you a minute ago, I don't
remember. I don't know.

speaker: Q
text: So you don't recall whether you were
aware and you also don't recall whether you saw it; is
that correct?

speaker: A
text: Right. As I told you, what we got in
terms of documents before filing -- are you asking
before filing the First Amended or the original?

speaker: Q
text: The First Amended.

speaker: A
text: First Amended. Well, anyway, what we had
was a whole series of accordion files that we were
told was the entire file maintained by op. man., which
stood at the time for operations management, and it
was -- I don't know how many. It was like a bunch --
you know, accordion folders, you know, maybe that thick,
a couple, three or four inches, and it was a bunch of
those. Like three or four, I guess. Is that a bunch?
I don't know. Anyway, three or four or five.
And Jim Smith and I both went through
those folders and went through all the paper in there.
And then I know we talked to various people at GFC.
And sitting here now, that was -- let's
see, that was 2003. So I didn't go back through those
folders to prepare for this deposition, and what all is
in there, I'm not exactly sure, sitting here now two
years later.

speaker: Q
text: And looking at Exhibit 417 doesn't
refresh your recollection as to whether you had seen the
phone log prior to the time that you filed the First
Amended Complaint; is that correct?

speaker: A
text: Well, it's a pretty big document. So,
it's not like I've looked at it. I've glanced at the
first page or two and kind of skimmed through it here.
Doesn't really refresh my recollection.
You know, like I say, if it was in that batch of
documents that came over, then we would have looked at
it. We were told we got op. man.'s entire file.
Whether that's accurate, I don't know. But we were told
we had the entire file of op. man., which was the unit
that was running the loan at that point. So, we went
through what we thought was their entire file.

speaker: Q
text: If you had been aware of the existence of
the GFC phone log relating to the Cave-Corp transaction
by the time the First Amended Complaint was filed,
wouldn't you have identified it in your initial
disclosure statement in this case?

speaker: A
text: I don't know.
I mean, I don't remember what I
identified in my initial disclosure statement. So... I
think -- plus, you got to realize, what we're -- when I
do the disclosure statement -- is that after you filed
your counterclaim? I guess it would have been.
But my perception of this case -- I know
you're here deposing me on your counterclaim. Well, to
be candid, I never viewed the counterclaim as any big
deal or any big threat. It was like always something
that obviously you were operating on the idea that the
best defense is a good offense.
So when I did the disclosure statement,
I'm sure it was oriented towards the -- at that time,
increasing wealth of good evidence that we had that your
clients committed fraud. Because I viewed this as a
plaintiff's case. I viewed the thrust of the case as
going after Hallidone and showing what they had done
here in terms of hiding the ball.
So whether I would have spent much time
developing a defense to your abuse-of-process
counterclaim, I don't think I really paid it a lot of
attention. So -- anyway. But without looking at the
disclosure statement, I don't remember what was in
there. That would've been filed about two years ago.

speaker: Q
text: Move to strike the response of the
witness as nonresponsive to the question.
If you had been aware of the existence of
the phone log, don't you believe that the matters
recorded in it would have borne upon the allegations
asserted by you in your Complaint against Hallidone
and Cave-Corp?

speaker: A
text: I don't know what's in there. If you
want to point out something to me, I'll try and take a
look at it.

speaker: Q
text: Stacy, you first told me that you couldn't
recall whether you'd ever seen it before without looking
at it, and now you have it in front of you. If you need
more time to look at it, please take the time to look at
it so that we can know whether it refreshes your
recollection.
And, also, given the way that you're
conducting your deposition, I'm certainly not going to
agree that it's only going to be limited to a particular
amount of time at this point.

speaker: A
text: Listen, Preston, this looks like about 80
or a hundred pages. Now, if you think I'm going to sit
here and read this, I'm not. I'm not going to take that
much time. If you think I'm going to spend more than a
day here for you to take my deposition, then I'll
probably move for a protective order, because I'm busy.
I got a lot going on. I just finished a two-week jury
trial on RICO where I represented a plaintiff and we won
the case, and I've got to catch up with all my other
files. So, I'm not going to spend a week here for you
to take a deposition or some ridiculous, inordinate
amount of time. So, anyway --
MR. Barnum: Perhaps then you could
limit yourself to answering the questions, Ms. King, and
you'll save us all a lot of time because we also have
busy schedules.
THE WITNESS: I'll answer the question as
I see fit based on what the question is. Okay? If you
think I'm going to arbitrarily let you unilaterally
decide what kind of answers I should give, I won't do
that. Okay? I'll give the best answer I'm capable of
giving.
So -- but it's going to take a long time
if you want me to read every single page. And look at
this thing. I don't know how many pages it is, but it's
a lot. That would take -- for me to really read it
would probably take about an hour, maybe an hour and a
half.

speaker: Q
text: BY MR. Bond: If you had known at the
time that you filed the First Amended Complaint in this
case that Greerborne had a policy of recording
essentially every conversation it had relating to the
Cave-Corp transaction, would you have disclosed that in
your initial disclosure statement as relevant to -- as
information relevant to the acquisition - excuse me, the
accusations made in the First Amended Complaint?
Ms. Grundle: Object to the form of the
question.

speaker: A
text: Would I have disclosed the policy?

speaker: Q
text: BY MR. Bond: Yes.

speaker: A
text: I don't know. I don't know -- I'm not
sure I would have, because I don't know why the very
fact of the policy is something that would be disclosed
in a disclosure statement.
If there's something in the phone records
that seems relevant defensively or offensively, then you
would disclose it, I would suppose, if you think it's
relevant. But just to disclose the fact that there's a
policy? I don't know -- I don't see why that's
important. But if you're asking me to guess, I don't
remember -- if you want to put the disclosure statement
in front of me, maybe I can try and refresh my
recollection.

speaker: Q
text: Since Mr. Smith's testimony, have you gone
back and reviewed any of the financial statements of
Cave-Corp that were submitted to Hal -- I mean that were
submitted to GFC?

speaker: A
text: No, except that a couple minutes ago --
while I was sitting in this chair before the deposition
started, I was glancing through this statement of facts
that I looked at this morning, and one of the financial
statements is in here and I looked at the front page.
That's all I looked at. In other words -- and it's
Exhibit 293 to the depo. And I looked at just the title
page. That's the only financial statement.
But I remember -- I mean they were
such -- they're an important part of the case. I
remember roughly what's in the financial statements.

speaker: Q
text: Since Mr. Smith's deposition was taken,
have you gone back and reviewed any of the monthly
financial statements from Cave-Corp that were submitted
to GFC?

speaker: A
text: No.

speaker: Q
text: Since Mr. Smith's deposition, have you
gone back and reviewed any documents bearing upon the
issue of whether the sole basis upon which GFC made the
Cave-Corp loan was the Hallidone guaranty?

speaker: A
text: No.
You're asking me if I've reviewed any of
those documents that relate to that issue, right?

speaker: Q
text: I asked if you had reviewed any documents
bearing upon the issue of whether the sole basis upon
which GFC made the Cave-Corp loan was the Hallidone
guaranty.

speaker: A
text: No, I haven't reviewed any documents like
that in the time from Smith's deposition and now. I've
obviously looked at documents before then.

speaker: Q
text: Since Mr. Smith's deposition, have you had
any discussions with Mr. Smith relating to anyone else
about GFC's internal memoranda prior to the expiration
of the Hallidone guaranty which indicated that the
transaction was not performing and needed to be
restructured?

speaker: A
text: Let me just make it simple.
From Mr. Smith's deposition 'til now, I haven't had
discussions with anybody about any internal GFC memoranda -
whether that one or any others.

speaker: Q
text: During the time period of June / July '03,
who did you work most closely with at GFC?

speaker: A
text: Probably two people - Marilyn Gates and Ernie
Ramirez. There were other people, but they were the two
I probably worked with most closely.

speaker: Q
text: In preparation for your deposition today,
have you gone back and reviewed any documents which have
been marked as exhibits to depositions in this case?

speaker: A
text: Just the ones that are attached to this
Statement of Facts, and there's all kinds of things
attached to it, some of which are deposition exhibits in
this case, and others of which I think are not. I think
most of what's attached here are probably deposition
exhibits.

speaker: Q
text: Okay --

speaker: A
text: And I didn't review every exhibit there.
I just reviewed some of them.

speaker: Q
text: Okay. So at most it would just be what's
contained in that package in terms of exhibits that you
reviewed?

speaker: A
text: I believe that's right.

speaker: Q
text: In preparation for your deposition today,
have you at any time gone back and reviewed any of the
deposition testimony that's been given in this case?

speaker: A
text: No. I meant to, but I didn't really have
the time to do it. And I didn't -- I would have had to
come in about 4:00 this morning instead of like 6:00.
So the answer is no.

speaker: Q
text: Was this the first case in which you
acted as counsel for Greerborne Financial Corporation?

speaker: A
text: I believe so.

speaker: Q
text: How did you come to obtain this business
from GFC?

speaker: A
text: Jim Smith. He found the client -- or met
someone at Greerborne.

speaker: Q
text: Prior to getting the case through Jim
Smith, had you done anything to try to recruit business
from GFC?

speaker: A
text: No, I don't think so. It was just Jim
Smith. He met Ward Clark in some sort of church group,
and that was the connection. And then Jim set up a
meeting -- I remember there was a lunch meeting with
myself, Jim Smith, Ward Clark, Ernie Ramirez, and that
was after Jim had met Ward in this church group. So
that was the first contact. We never had tried to
approach GFC about doing work before that.

speaker: Q
text: Was that luncheon prior to the time you
had heard about this case?

speaker: A
text: I don't remember. It was right around
the time. Maybe it was right after this case came up or
maybe it was right before. I think it might have been
right before, but I'm not sure.
MR. Bond: Could you hand the witness
Exhibit 500, please.
No, I'm sorry. I apologize. Could you
hand the exhibit, excuse me witness Exhibit 515, please.
Ms. Grundle: No.
MR. Bond: All right. I think I've
got extra copies.
Ms. Grundle: I'll give her mine.
MR. Bond: Would you like a copy,
Jane?
Ms. Grundle: No, that's fine.
MR. Bond: Okay.

speaker: Q
text: BY MR. Bond: Ms. King, Exhibit 515 to
Mr. Smith's deposition he identified as being copies of
the billing statements from your firm from the first
that your firm heard of the case through and including

speaker: A
text: Yes.

speaker: Q
text: As part of responding to the subpoena
that we served on your firm, did you go back at any time
and either help locate or review what was located for
response to that subpoena?

speaker: A
text: I did not personally do that. Jim Smith
and, I think, someone, probably Debbie Williams, our
manager, office manager, did that.

speaker: Q
text: Do you recognize Exhibit 515 as your
firm's billing statements for the period from when you
first heard of the case until July 28 of 2003?

speaker: A
text: Yes.

speaker: Q
text: The statement for June indicates that
while there - there were apparently in excess of 17 hours
of time invested between June 22 and the end of the month,
there were no charges made to GFC for that work. Do you
see that?

speaker: A
text: Yes.

speaker: Q
text: Do you have a recollection of why you did
those first 17-plus hours of work for GFC at no charge?

speaker: A
text: Not really. Jim Smith was the supervising
attorney for billing, because he had generated the
client, and, you know, I don't know, whatever he said.
We do -- I mean, we're fairly marketing oriented in
terms of billing to clients. Clients get bugged by
paying a lot of money up front to get up to speed on a
file, that sort of thing. So it's common for us to make
billing concessions, particularly with a new client, you
know. We're trying to impress them with our efficiency
or something.
But what he was doing here -- he would
have made the call on this, because he was the billing
attorney, and I'm not sure what he was doing. Maybe it
was just something along those lines.

speaker: Q
text: Mr. Smith indicated that the billing rate
for, I believe, both of - both you and he was agreed to be
$115 an hour. Is that your recollection as well?

speaker: A
text: At the outset of the case?

speaker: Q
text: Yes.

speaker: A
text: Yeah, at the outset of the case that was
the billing rate.

speaker: Q
text: Did your billing rate increase at some
point after that?

speaker: A
text: Yeah, at some point it did.

speaker: Q
text: And to what did it increase?

speaker: A
text: I think maybe 150.

speaker: Q
text: Mr. Smith indicated that the initial rate
of 115 was below what he referred to as your,
quote-unquote, street rates. Would you agree with that?

speaker: A
text: Yeah, we have street rates, but they're
not -- most of our work is institutional, and we don't
use the street rates for institutional clients where
there's either the actuality or the possibility of
getting a large volume of work. It's just like a
discount, basically. If you get a bunch of work from
somebody, you're willing to, you know, cut your profit
margin a little bit, I guess.

speaker: Q
text: And so is it fair for us to understand
that in the time frame of June and July of 2003 you
hoped that - that you would be getting a fair amount of
work from GFC in the future?

speaker: A
text: Any time you have a shot at getting
institutional work from a large institution, whether
it's -- I represent Bank of Antartica, Fifth Interstate --
there's two factors, really. One is you hope to get
volume from them. Okay? And, two, is the way this
industry -- and you just started your own firm, I'm sure
you're aware of it -- the leverage is such if you're a
big institution and you know they're going to pay their
bill, you know, like in a small individual you got
accounts receivable problems, they don't pay, stuff like
that, if you have a chance to do work for a large
financial institution, at least if you're a firm that's
smaller like ours, you usually cut your rate both
because, gee, maybe, you'll get some volume, and, two,
you're not going to have an accounts receivable problem,
and, three, the reality is most big corporations take
their work to big firms like Janes', and you have to
differentiate yourself in some way if you're a small
firm.
And so, you know, in addition to being as
good as lawyers or better than them, you also have to
differentiate yourself in terms of pricing. That's been
our marketing philosophy, I suppose. It was no
different with this client than any other. That's how
we got Bank of Antarctica or Fifth Interstate.

speaker: Q
text: So would it be fair for us to understand
that in the time frame of June, July of 2003 you hoped
that you would be getting a substantial amount of work
from GFC in the future?

speaker: A
text: Any time I work for a large financial
institution, I'm doing my best to do a good job for them
in the hope that I will get more work in the future, and
GFC was absolutely no different than how I would
approach a Bank of Antarctica or Fifth Interstate file or
any other client like that where they've got a steady
flow of work.

speaker: Q
text: And did you believe that the result in
this case would have a substantial bearing on whether
you would get a substantial - or substantial further
business from GFC in the future?

speaker: A
text: I didn't know. What I -- what I really
thought at the time, as I got into this case, what I
realized was that this was a great fraud case against
your client, because we had really compelling -- the
evidence getting better showing fraud by Hallidone.
And what I viewed it as was a case where,
wow, you know, it's got a bunch of really nice variables
that all fit together. You've got real strong fraud and
good evidence of it, you know, misrepresentations,
omissions, half truths. You've got that. You've got a
huge corporate defendant. They've got a lot of money.
You've got a reasonable claim for punitive damages. You
can blackboard some large numbers for compensatory
damages as well as ask for some really large numbers for
puni's, and I just thought, wow, this case could really
go well. And if that resulted in more work from
Greerborne, great, and if it didn't, it's still a great
case and I wanted to, you know, process it.
So I don't know what goes into -- I don't
know what goes into their thinking, but if they're like
most clients, you get a good result, they like it. My
observation is commercial clients pay attention to
results. Most clients do, I guess. But I mostly do
commercial work.

speaker: Q
text: The -- the prebills from your firm for
the time from the beginning of the work on this matter
until May 28 were given to us by Mr. Smith at his
deposition, and I don't see them right now, but they
indicated that at least during the month of May your
travel time was billed at half of the 115-per-hour
rate. Do you recall that being the case?

speaker: A
text: Yeah. What I recall is that GFC told us
that was their standard policy. So we complied with
that standard policy, that if you travel, you bill half
rate. And we did our best throughout the case to comply
with that.

speaker: Q
text: During the time period from what appears
to be May 21 or May 22 when your firm was first
contacted about this case in 2003 through the time that
the First Amended Complaint was filed, were you ever
under the impression that anyone at GFC wanted to take a
particularly aggressive stance in this case against
Hallidone?

speaker: A
text: What do you mean by "particularly
aggressive"? I mean, if you're running a plaintiff's
case, you have to -- I don't know if "aggressive" is the
right word. The point is you have to process the case.
You have to pursue it vigorously, is a better way to put
it.
And I don't remember what -- I don't know
what the people at Greerborne thought, but my philosophy
of a plaintiff's case is you push -- you push
appropriate theories in a vigorous fashion, and you also
try and, you know, get it to trial as quickly as
possible.
And so I had the approach to this case
of, let's do the discovery we've got to do, but let's
get it to trial as soon as we can. I remember talking
to Stacy Palumbo about that, even. You know, he was
saying "You can't go faster than this. You're going as
fast as you can expect us to go." And he was
reasonable. He was allowing me to process the case
towards a trial that was nearer rather than further
away.

speaker: Q
text: Move to strike the answer as
nonresponsive.
During the time period when your firm
first heard about this case through the time period that
the First Amended Complaint was filed, were you ever
under the impression that anyone at GFC wanted to take a
particularly aggressive stance in this case against
Hallidone, i.e., more aggressive than they would have
taken in other cases?

speaker: A
text: I wasn't under any impression like that.
I felt like -- this was no different than a smaller case
for them or for anyone else.
If you've got a case which has really
compelling evidence of fraud and gets better as you go,
then you push it. You know, you deal with the case
you've got. If I had another case for another client
that was like this, I wouldn't push it any differently.
I'd approach it same.

speaker: Q
text: Move to strike the last portion of the
answer as nonresponsive.
MR. Barnum: In order to try and avoid
some problems, because I can see that as things are
going there's no possibility we'll get done today, I'd
